  "content": "# Specification-Driven Development\n\n## Overview\n\nSpecification-Driven Development (SDD) is an approach where detailed specifications serve as the primary artifact that drives the entire development process. Unlike traditional \"code-first\" approaches, SDD emphasizes creating comprehensive, unambiguous specifications before implementation begins. This approach is particularly valuable in AI-assisted development, where clear specifications directly inform AI code generation.\n\n## Core Principles\n\n### 1. Specification as Source of Truth\n\n```markdown\n## Specification Hierarchy\n\n┌─────────────────────────────────────┐\n│     Business Requirements           │  ← Strategic goals\n├─────────────────────────────────────┤\n│     Feature Specifications          │  ← What to build\n├─────────────────────────────────────┤\n│     Technical Specifications        │  ← How it works\n├─────────────────────────────────────┤\n│     API Contracts                  │  ← Interface definitions\n├─────────────────────────────────────┤\n│     Test Specifications            │  ← Acceptance criteria\n└─────────────────────────────────────┘\n```\n\n### 2. Formal Specification Languages\n\n```gherkin\n## Gherkin for Behavioral Specifications\nFeature: Order Processing System\n\n  Background:\n    Given the inventory service is available\n    And the payment gateway is operational\n\n  Scenario: Successful order placement\n    Given a customer has items in their cart totaling $150\n    When the customer submits the order\n    Then the inventory should be reserved\n    And payment should be processed\n    And order confirmation should be sent\n\n  Scenario: Payment failure handling\n    Given a customer has a pending order\n    When payment is rejected by the gateway\n    Then the inventory reservation should be released\n    And the customer should be notified\n    And the order status should be \"payment_failed\"\n```\n\n```typescript\n// TypeScript Interface Specifications\ninterface OrderProcessingSpec {\n  processOrder(input: OrderInput): Promise<OrderResult>;\n  \n  // Preconditions\n  preconditions: {\n    inventoryAvailable: (items: OrderItem[]) => Promise<boolean>;\n    customerValid: (customerId: string) => Promise<boolean>;\n    paymentMethodValid: (payment: PaymentMethod) => boolean;\n  };\n  \n  // Postconditions\n  postconditions: {\n    onSuccess: (result: OrderResult) => void;\n    onFailure: (error: OrderError) => void;\n  };\n  \n  // Invariants\n  invariants: {\n    orderTotal: (items: OrderItem[], payment: Payment) => boolean;\n    orderId: (order: Order) => boolean;\n  };\n}\n```\n\n### 3. Executable Specifications\n\n```python\n# Python with behave for executable specifications\nfrom behave import given, when, then\nfrom orders import OrderProcessor\n\n@given(\"the order processor is initialized\")\ndef step_order_processor_initialized(context):\n    context.processor = OrderProcessor(\n        inventory_service=context.inventory,\n        payment_service=context.payment,\n        notification_service=context.notification\n    )\n\n@when(\"the customer submits an order with {item_count} items\")\ndef step_customer_submits_order(context, item_count):\n    context.order = context.processor.create_order(\n        items=context.items[:int(item_count)],\n        customer_id=context.customer_id\n    )\n\n@then(\"the order should be confirmed with status {status}\")\ndef step_order_confirmed_with_status(context, status):\n    assert context.order.status == status\n    context.processor.audit_log.record(\n        event=\"order_confirmed\",\n        order_id=context.order.id,\n        status=status\n    )\n```\n\n## SDD Workflow\n\n```\n┌────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐\n│                    SDD Development Cycle                        │\n├────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤\n│                                                                │\n│   1. ]\n```\n\n## Benefits of Specification-Driven Development\n\n| Benefit | Description |\n|---------|-------------|\n| **Clarity** | Specifications eliminate ambiguity |\n| **Testability** | Executable and tactical design patterns.\n\n## Core Concepts\n\n### Strategic Design Patterns\n\nStrategic design addresses the \"big picture\" of the domain architecture:\n\n```\n┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐\n│                    DOMAIN LANDSCAPE ┌──────────┐ │\n│   │   CORE      │         │   CORE      │         │ SUPPORTED│ │\n│   │   DOMAIN    │◄────────┤   DOMAIN    │────────►│  DOMAIN  │ │\n│   │             │  Shared │             │ └─────────────┘         └──────────┘ │\n│                                                                 │\n│   ┌───────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐   │\n│   │ │\n└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘\n```\n\n### The Ubiquitous Language\n\nThe Ubiquitous Language is the shared vocabulary used by all team }\n}\n```\n\n## Bounded Contexts\n\nA Bounded Context is a boundary within which a particular domain model applies:\n\n```typescript\n// Order Bounded Context\nnamespace OrderContext {\n  export SHIPPED = 'SHIPPED',\n    DELIVERED = 'DELIVERED',\n    CANCELLED = 'CANCELLED'\n  }\n\n  export class Order {\n    submit(): void {\n      if (this.status !== OrderStatus.DRAFT) {\n        throw new  private status: OrderStatus;\n  private lineItems: OrderLineItem[];\n  private readonly createdAt: DateTime;\n  private version: number;\n\n  constructor(id: OrderId, lineItems: OrderLineItem[]) {\n get total(): Money { return this.lineItems.reduce((sum, item) => sum.add(item.subtotal), Money.zero()); }\n  \n  isSameIdentity(other: Order): boolean {\n    return this.id.equals(other.id);\n  }\n}\n```\n\n### Value Objects\n\n```typescript\nclass Money implements ValueObject {\n  private readonly amount: number;\n  private readonly currency: Currency;\n\n  constructor(amount: number, this.currency);\n  }\n\n  multiply(factor: number): Money {\n    return new Money(this.amount * factor, this.currency);\n  }\n\n  private ensureSameCurrency(other: Money): void {\n    if (!this.currency.equals(other.currency)) {\n      throw new CurrencyMismatchError();\n    }\n  }\n}\n```\n\n### Aggregates\n\n```typescript\n// Order Aggregate Root\nclass Order implements AggregateRoot<OrderId> {\n  private _id: OrderId;\n  private _status: OrderStatus;\n  private _lineItems: OrderLineItem[];\n  private _customer: CustomerReference;\n  private _shippingAddress: }\n}\n```\n\n### Domain Events\n\n```typescript\n// Domain Event\nclass OrderSubmitted implements DomainEvent {\n  readonly orderId: OrderId;\n  readonly customerId: CustomerId;\n  readonly totalAmount: Money;\n  readonly submittedAt: DateTime;\n  readonly eventId: EventId;\n  readonly occurredAt: DateTime;\n\n  constructor(\n    orderId: OrderId,\n    customerId: CustomerId,\n this._status = OrderStatus.SUBMITTED;\n    \n    // Raise domain event\n    this.recordEvent(new OrderSubmitted(\n      this._id,\n      this._customerId,\n      this.calculateTotal()\n    ));\n  }\n}\n```\n\n### Repositories\n\n```typescript\ninterface OrderRepository {\n  findById(id: OrderId): Promise<Order | null>;\n  findByCustomerId(customerId: CustomerId): Promise<Order[]>;\n $5`,\n        [order.id.value, order.status, order.createdAt, order.version + 1, OrderMapper.toPersistence(order)]\n      );\n      \n      // Publish domain events\n      for (const event of order.getUncommittedEvents()) {\n        await this.eventStore.publish(event);\n      }\n    });\n  }\n}\n```\n\n### Domain Services\n\n```typescript\nclass OrderFactory implements DomainService {\n  constructor(\n    private readonly productRepository: ProductRepository,\n    private readonly pricingService: PricingService\n  ) {}\n\n  createOrder(customerId: CustomerId, items: OrderItemInput[]):   \n      const price = this.pricingService.calculatePrice(\n        product.id,\n        input.quantity,\n        customerId\n      );\n      \n      return OrderLineItem.create(product, input.quantity, price);\n    });\n    \n    const orderId = OrderId.generate();\n    return new Order(orderId, customerId, lineItems);\n  }\n}\n```\n\n## Context Mapping\n\n```typescript\n// Context }\n};\n```\n\n## DDD in AI-Assisted Development\n\n```typescript\n// AI Prompts for DDD\nconst dddPrompt = `Implement the following domain model following DDD principles:\n\nDomain: E-commerce Order   "content": "# Clean Architecture\n\n## Overview\n\nClean Architecture is a software design philosophy introduced by Robert C. Martin (Uncle Bob) that emphasizes the separation of concerns through architectural layers. The core principle is that business rules and application logic should not depend on external frameworks, databases, or delivery mechanisms.\n\n## Core Principles\n\n### The Dependency Rule\n\n```\n                    ┌───────────────────────────────────────┐\n                    │          Frameworks & Tools          │  ← External\n                    │  (Web, DB, UI, External Services)   │\n                    └───────────────────┬───────────────────┘\n                                        │\n                    ┌───────────────────▼───────────────────┐\n                    │         Interface Adapters          │  ← Entry/Exit\n                    │  (Controllers, Gateways, Presenters)│\n                    └───────────────────┬───────────────────┘\n                                        │\n                    ┌───────────────────▼───────────────────┐\n                    │          Application Services        │  ← Use Cases\n                    │  (Interactors, Use Case Coordinators)│\n                    └───────────────────┬───────────────────┘\n                                        │\n                    ┌───────────────────▼───────────────────┐\n                    │           Domain Layer              │  ← Business Rules\n                    │  (Entities, Domain Services, Value Objects)│\n                    └───────────────────────────────────────┘\n\n     Source code dependencies point INWARD toward the domain.\n     Inner layers do NOT know about outer layers.\n```\n\n### Key Principles\n\n1. **Independence of Frameworks**: Business logic independent of frameworks\n2. **Testability**: Business rules testable without UI, DB, or external systems\n3. **Independence of UI**: UI can change without changing business logic\n4. **Independence of Database**: Business logic independent of database\n5. **Independence of External Agencies**: Business rules don't know about outside world\n\n## Layer Structure\n\n```typescript\nsrc/\n├── enterprise/\n│   └── business-rules/        # Domain Layer ( innermost)\n│       ├── entities/\n│       ├── value-objects/\n│       ├── domain-services/\n│       └── events/\n│\n├── application/\n│   ├── use-cases/            # Application Services\n│   │   ├── create-order/\n│   │   ├── process-payment/\n│   │   └── ship-order/\n│   ├── ports/\n│   │   ├── inbound/          # Input ports (use case interfaces)\n│   │   └── outbound/         # Output ports (repository interfaces)\n│   └── coordinators/\n│\n├── adapters/\n│   ├── inbound/              # Interface Adapters\n│   │   ├── http/             # HTTP controllers\n│   │   ├── grpc/\n│   │   └── messaging/\n│   ├── outbound/\n│   │   ├── persistence/      # Database adapters\n│   │   ├── external-api/     # External service clients\n│   │   └── events/           # Event publishers\n│   └── presenters/\n│\n└── frameworks/\n    ├── web/                  # Frameworks & Drivers\n    │   ├── express/\n    │   ├── fastify/\n    │   └── swagger/\n    ├── database/\n    │   ├── typeorm/\n    │   ├── prisma/\n    │   └── mongoose/\n    └── external/\n        ├── stripe/\n        ├── sendgrid/\n        └── aws/\n```\n\n## Implementation Examples\n\n### Domain Layer (Enterprise Business Rules)\n\n```typescript\n// entities/order.ts\nimport { Entity } from '../../shared/entity';\nimport { Money } from '../../value-objects/money';\nimport { OrderId } from '../../value-objects/order-id';\nimport { OrderStatus } from './order-status';\nimport { OrderLineItem } from './order-line-item';\n\nexport interface OrderProps {\n  id: OrderId;\n  customerId: string;\n  lineItems: OrderLineItem[];\n  status: OrderStatus;\n  createdAt: Date;\n}\n\nexport class Order extends Entity<OrderId, OrderProps> {\n  private constructor(props: OrderProps) {\n    super(props);\n  }\n\n  static create(props: OrderProps): Order {\n    const order = new Order(props);\n    order.validate();\n    return order;\n  }\n\n  private validate(): void {\n    if (this._props.lineItems.length === 0) {\n      throw new Error('Order must have at least one line item');\n    }\n    if (!this._props.status) {\n      throw new Error('Order must have a status');\n    }\n  }\n\n  get total(): Money {\n    return this._props.lineItems.reduce(\n      (sum, item) => sum.add(item.subtotal),\n      Money.zero()\n    );\n   "content": "# Vertical Slice Architecture\n\n## Overview\n\nVertical Slice Architecture is an approach to organizing code by feature slices rather than by technical layers. Each slice contains all the components needed to implement a specific feature, from the user interface to the database access. This contrasts with traditional layered architectures where code is organized by technical type (controllers, services, repositories).\n\n## Core Concept\n\n```\nTraditional Layered Architecture          Vertical Slice Architecture\n┌──────────────────────────────────┐     ┌──────────────────────────────────┐\n│          Presentation            │     │      Feature: User Auth          │\n├──────────┬──────────┬──────────┤     ├──────────────────────────────────┤\n│Controllers│Controllers│Controllers│     │  UserAuthController            │\n├──────────┴──────────┴──────────┤     │  LoginUseCase                  │\n│           Business Logic        │     │  AuthRepository                │\n├──────────┬──────────┬──────────┤     │  AuthEvents                    │\n│ Services │ |\n|---------|-------------|\n| **Feature Isolation** | Changes to one feature don't affect others |\n| **Team Scalability** | Teams can work on different features independently |\n| **Faster Development** | All code for a feature in one place |\n| **Better Testing** | Tests are focused on single features |\n| **Reduced Cognitive Load** | Don't need to understand entire codebase |\n| **Easier Refactoring** | Feature boundaries make refactoring safer |\n\n## When to Use\n\n✅ **Use Vertical Slice Architecture when:**\n- Building feature-rich applications\n- Working in cross-functional teams\n- Prioritizing feature delivery over technical layers\n- Using frameworks that support feature-based organization (NestJS, Angular)\n\n❌ **Consider alternatives when:**\n- Building simple CRUD applications\n- Team is small and highly cohesive\n- Strict technical layering provides more value\n\n## References\n\n- \"Vertical Slice Architecture\" by Jimmy Bogard\n-   "content": "# Domain Event Storytelling\n\n## Overview\n\nDomain Event Storytelling is a technique that uses narrative structures to communicate and explore domain events. It extends Event Storming by adding temporal context, character motivations, and story arcs to make domain events more meaningful and memorable. This approach leverages the human brain's natural affinity for stories to improve domain understanding.\n\n## Core Concept\n\n```\n┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐\n│                    DOMAIN EVENT STORYTELLING                             │\n├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤\n│                                                                       │\n│  STORY STRUCTURE → EVENT MAPPING                                       │\n│                                                                       │\n│  ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐   │\n│  │  Once upon a time...  (Initial State)                        │   │\n│  │      │                                                        │   │\n│  │      ▼                                                        │   │\n│  │  [Customer browses catalog]                                    │   │\n│  │      │                                                        │   │\n│  │      ▼                                                        │   │\n│  │  Every day...  (Recurring Pattern)                           │   │\n│  │      │                                                        │   │\n│  │      ▼                                                        │   │\n│  │  [Customer adds items to cart]                               │   │\n│  │      │                                                        │   │\n│  │      ▼                                                        │   │\n│  │  One day...  (Trigger Event)                                 │   │\n│  │      │                                                        │   │\n│  │      ▼                                                        │   │\n│  │  [Customer decides to checkout]                               │   │\n│  │      │                                                        │   │\n│  │      ▼                                                        │   │\n│  │  Because of that...  (Causal Chain)                          │   │\n│  │      │                                                        │   │\n│  │      ▼                                                        │   │\n│  │  [System validates inventory]                                │   │\n│  │      │                                                        │   │\n│  │      ▼                                                        │   │\n│  │  [Customer enters payment]                                  │   │\n│  │      │                                                        │   │\n│  │      ▼                                                        │   │\n│  │  [Payment is processed]                                     │   │\n│  │      │                                                        │   │\n│  │      ▼                                                        │   │\n│  │  Until finally...  (Resolution)                              │   │\n│  │      │                                                        │   │\n│  │      ▼                                                        │   │\n│  │  [Order is confirmed]                                       │   │\n│  │      │                                                        │   │\n│  │      ▼                                                        │   │\n│  │  And ever since...  (New Normal)                           │   │\n│  │      │                                                        │   │\n│  │      ▼                                                        │   │\n│  │  [Customer receives confirmation]                            │   │\n│  │                                                               │   │\n│  └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘   │\n│                                                                       │\n└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘\n```\n\n## Story Template\n\n```markdown\n## Domain Event Story Template\n\n### Title: [Descriptive name of the scenario]\n\n### Characters (Actors)\n- **Customer**: Primary actor who initiates actions\n- **System**: The software system being designed\n- **External Services**: Third-party systems involved\n\n### Setting (Context)\n- Where does this story take place?\n- What is the current state of the system?\n- What constraints exist?\n\n### Plot (Event Sequence)\n\n#### Act 1: Normal Operations\n```\n[Event]: Initial action in the story\nTrigger: What caused this event?\nActor: Who/what triggered it?\nOutcome: What happened as a result?\n```\n\n#### Act 2: Complication\n```\n[Event]: Something changes the flow\nTrigger: What disrupted the normal flow?\nDecision Point: What choices emerge?\n```\n\n#### Act 3: Resolution\n```\n[Event]: The story resolves\nOutcome: What is the final state?\nConsequence: What effects ripple outward?\n```\n\n### Key Events (Domain Events)\n1. [Event name] - [Brief description]\n2. [Event name] - [Brief description]\n...\n\n### Turning Points (Hotspots)\n- What questions arose?\n- What risks were identified?\n- What opportunities were discovered?\n\n### Moral (Lessons Learned)\n- What did we learn about the domain?\n- What should we remember for implementation?\n```\n\n## Example Story\n\n```markdown\n## Story: The Abandoned Cart Recovery\n\n### Characters\n- **E-commerce Customer**: Browse and shop\n- **Cart Service**: Manages shopping cart state\n- **Inventory Service**: Tracks product availability\n- **Email Service**: Sends notifications\n- **Marketing Team**: Wants to recover abandoned carts\n\n### Setting\nAn e-commerce platform where customers can browse products, add them to a cart, and complete purchases. The cart is persisted across sessions.\n\n### Plot\n\n#### Act 1: Normal Operations\n**Customer browses products**\n- Trigger: Customer visits the website\n- Action: Views product catalog\n- Outcome: Customer finds items of interest\n\n**Customer adds items to cart**\n- Trigger: Customer clicks \"Add to Cart\"\n- Action: System records items in cart\n- Outcome: Cart contains items, persists to database\n\n#### Act 2: Complication\n**Customer leaves without purchasing**\n- Trigger: Customer closes browser, abandons cart\n- Action: Cart remains in \"PENDING\" state\n- Decision: What should trigger a recovery attempt?\n\n**Inventory reservation expires**\n- Trigger: Time passes (24 hours)\n- Action: Reserved items are released\n- Decision: How do we handle pre-reserved items?\n\n#### Act 3: Resolution\n**Cart recovery notification sent**\n- Trigger: 1 hour after abandonment\n- Action: Email sent to customer\n- Outcome: Customer receives reminder\n\n**Customer returns and completes purchase**\n- Trigger: Customer clicks email link\n- Action: Cart restored with current prices\n- Outcome: Order placed, payment processed\n\n### Key Events\n1. `ItemAddedToCart` - Customer added item to cart\n2. `CartAbandoned` - Cart inactive for 2 hours\n3. `InventoryReservationExpired` - Reserved items released\n4. `RecoveryEmailSent` - Notification sent to customer\n5. `CartRestored` - Customer returned via link\n6. `OrderPlaced` - Customer completed purchase\n\n### Turning Points\n- **Question**: At what point should we consider a cart \"abandoned\"?\n- **Risk**: Customer might feel spammed with recovery emails\n- **Opportunity**: Personalize recovery based on cart contents\n\n### Moral\n- Event timing matters as much as event sequence\n- Customer communication must balance persistence with respect\n- External systems (inventory) affect customer experience\n```\n\n## Translating Stories to Code\n\n```typescript\n// From the story, we identify these domain events:\n\nnamespace CartEvents {\n  export class ItemAddedToCart implements DomainEvent {\n    readonly cartId: CartId;\n    readonly productId: ProductId;\n    readonly quantity: Quantity;\n    readonly addedAt: DateTime;\n\n    constructor(cartId: CartId, productId: ProductId, quantity: Quantity) {\n      this.cartId = cartId;\n      this.productId = productId;\n      this.quantity = quantity;\n      this.addedAt = DateTime.now();\n    }\n  }\n\n  export class CartAbandoned implements DomainEvent {\n    readonly cartId: CartId;\n    readonly items: CartItemSnapshot[];\n    readonly abandonedAt: DateTime;\n\n    constructor(cartId: CartId, items: CartItemSnapshot[]) {\n      this.cartId = cartId;\n      this.items = items;\n      this.abandonedAt = DateTime.now();\n    }\n  }\n\n  export class RecoveryEmailSent implements DomainEvent {\n    readonly cartId: CartId;\n    readonly customerEmail: Email;\n    readonly templateUsed: string;\n    readonly sentAt: DateTime;\n\n    constructor(cartId: CartId, customerEmail: Email, templateUsed: string) {\n      this.cartId = cartId;\n      this.customerEmail = customerEmail;\n      this.templateUsed = templateUsed;\n      this.sentAt = DateTime.now();\n    }\n  }\n\n  export class CartRestored implements DomainEvent {\n    readonly cartId: CartId;\n    readonly originalCartId: CartId;\n    readonly restoredAt: DateTime;\n\n    constructor(cartId: CartId, originalCartId: CartId) {\n      this.cartId = cartId;\n      this.originalCartId = originalCartId;\n      this.restoredAt = DateTime.now();\n    }\n  }\n}\n\n// Aggregate behavior from story\n\nclass Cart extends AggregateRoot<CartId> {\n  private status: CartStatus;\n  private items: CartItem[];\n  private lastActivityAt: DateTime;\n\n  constructor(id: CartId) {\n    super(id);\n    this.status = CartStatus.EMPTY;\n    this.items = [];\n    this.lastActivityAt = DateTime.now();\n  }\n\n  addItem(product: Product, quantity: Quantity): void {\n    if (this.status === CartStatus.ABANDONED) {\n      throw new CannotModifyAbandonedCartError();\n    }\n\n    const existing = this.items.find(i => i.productId.equals(product.id));\n    if (existing) {\n      existing.increaseQuantity(quantity);\n    } else {\n      this.items.push(CartItem.create(this.id, product, quantity));\n    }\n\n    this.status = this.items.length > 0 ? CartStatus.ACTIVE : CartStatus.EMPTY;\n    this.lastActivityAt = DateTime.now();\n    \n    this.recordEvent(new ItemAddedToCart(this.id, product.id, quantity));\n  }\n\n  markAsAbandoned(): void {\n    if (this.status !== CartStatus.ACTIVE) return;\n    \n    this.status = CartStatus.ABANDONED;\n    this.recordEvent(new CartAbandoned(this.id, this.snapshot()));\n  }\n\n  isEligibleForRecovery(afterHours: number = 2): boolean {\n    const hoursSinceActivity = DateTime.now().diff(this.lastActivityAt).hours;\n    return this.status === CartStatus.ABANDONED && \n           hoursSinceActivity >= afterHours &&\n           this.items.length > 0;\n  }\n}\n```\n\n## Story-Driven Testing\n\n```typescript\n// Feature: Cart Abandonment Recovery\nimport { describe, it, beforeEach } from 'vitest';\nimport { Cart } from './cart.aggregate';\nimport { CartStatus } from './cart-status';\nimport { Money } from '../../shared/money';\n\ndescribe('Cart Abandonment Recovery Story', () => {\n  describe('Act 1: Normal Operations', () => {\n    it('customer can add items to their cart', () => {\n      const cart = Cart.create(CartId.generate());\n      const product = ProductFixture.create({ price: Money.fromAmount(29.99) });\n      \n      cart.addItem(product, Quantity.of(2));\n      \n      expect(cart.items).toHaveLength(2);\n      expect(cart.total).toEqual(Money.fromAmount(59.98));\n    });\n  });\n\n  describe('Act 2: Complication', () => {\n    it('cart becomes abandoned after inactivity', () => {\n      const cart = Cart.create(CartId.generate());\n      cart.addItem(ProductFixture.create(), Quantity.of(1));\n      \n      // Simulate time passing\n      cart.markAsAbandoned();\n      \n      expect(cart.status).toBe(CartStatus.ABANDONED);\n    });\n\n    it('cannot modify abandoned cart', () => {\n      const cart = Cart.create(CartId.generate());\n      cart.addItem(ProductFixture.create(), Quantity.of(1));\n      cart.markAsAbandoned();\n      \n      expect(() => {\n        cart.addItem(ProductFixture.create(), Quantity.of(1));\n      }).toThrow(CannotModifyAbandonedCartError);\n    });\n  });\n\n  describe('Act 3: Resolution', () => {\n    it('cart can be recovered via email link', () => {\n      const abandonedCart = Cart.create(CartId.generate());\n      abandonedCart.addItem(ProductFixture.create(), Quantity.of(1));\n      abandonedCart.markAsAbandoned();\n      \n      const recoveredCart = Cart.recover(abandonedCart.id);\n      \n      expect(recoveredCart.status).toBe(CartStatus.ACTIVE);\n      expect(recoveredCart.items).toHaveLength(1);\n    });\n\n    it('restored cart reflects current prices', () => {\n      const abandonedCart = Cart.create(CartId.generate());\n      abandonedCart.addItem(ProductFixture.create({ \n        price: Money.fromAmount(29.99) \n      }), Quantity.of(1));\n      abandonedCart.markAsAbandoned();\n      \n      // Price changed while abandoned\n      const recoveredCart = Cart.recover(abandonedCart.id);\n      \n      expect(recoveredCart.items[0].unitPrice).toEqual(\n        Money.fromAmount(34.99) // Current price\n      );\n    });\n  });\n});\n```\n\n## Benefits of Storytelling\n\n| Aspect | Benefit |\n|---------|---------|\n| **Recall** | Stories are easier to remember than lists |\n| **Context** | Events have clear \"why\" not just \"what\" |\n| **Engagement** | Stories capture attention and imagination |\n| **Alignment** | Common narrative unites team understanding |\n| **Exploration** | Stories naturally surface edge cases |\n\n## AI Integration\n\n```markdown\n## AI Prompt for Story Generation\n\nGenerate a domain event story from the following requirements:\n\n```\nFeature: User subscription management\n\nRequirements:\n- Users can subscribe to monthly plans\n- Subscriptions Character descriptions\n2. Story with three acts\n3. Key domain events\n4. Edge cases discovered\n5. Questions for domain expert\n```\n\n## Best Practices\n\n1. **Use Real Language**: Avoid technical jargon in stories\n2. **Include Failures**: What happens when things go wrong?\n3. **Show Causality**: Events should connect logically\n4. **Keep it Concise**: Stories should be digestible\n5. **Iterate**: Refine stories with domain experts\n\n## References\n\n- \"Domain Storytelling\" by Stefan Hofer\n- EventStorming.com\n- \"User Story Mapping\" by Jeff Patton\n",

{
  "content": "# Specification by Example\n\n## Overview\n\nSpecification by Example (SbE) is a requirements gathering and testing approach that uses concrete examples to illustrate and validate business requirements. Popularized by Gojko Adzic, this technique replaces abstract specifications with real-world scenarios that all stakeholders can understand and verify.\n\n## Core Concept\n\n```\n┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐\n│              SPECIFICATION BY EXAMPLE WORKFLOW                         │\n├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤\n│                                                                  │\n│  1. GATHER EXAMPLES              2. DERIVE SPECIFICATIONS          │\n│  ┌───────────────────┐           ┌───────────────────┐             │\n│  │ Business rules   │           │ Executable specs  │             │\n│  │ expressed as    │──────────►│ written in       │             │\n│  │ concrete        │   Derive   │ Gherkin/other    │             │\n│  │ examples        │            │ DSL              │             │\n│  └───────────────────┘           └───────────────────┘             │\n│           │                              │                         │\n│           │                              │                         │\n│           ▼                              ▼                         │\n│  3. AUTOMATE VALIDATION        4. LIVING DOCUMENTATION           │\n│  ┌───────────────────┐           ┌───────────────────┐             │\n│  │ Examples become   │           │ Documentation    │             │\n│  │ automated tests  │◄─────────►│ always in sync   │             │\n│  └───────────────────┘   Sync    with code             │\n│                                                                  │\n└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘\n```\n\n## Key Concepts\n\n### Business Examples\n\n```markdown\n## Example: Shopping Cart Discount Rules\n\n### Scenario 1: First-time customer gets welcome discount\n**Given** a customer with no previous orders\n**When** they apply the code \"WELCOME10\"\n**Then** they receive 10% off their first order\n**And** the discount is capped at $20\n\n### Scenario 2: Loyalty discount for returning customers\n**Given** a customer with more than 5 previous orders\n**When** their cart total exceeds $100\n**Then** they automatically receive 15% discount\n**And** no promo code is required\n\n### Scenario 3: Promotional events\n**Given** the store is running a \"BOGO\" sale\n**When** a customer adds 2 identical items to cart\n**Then** they are charged for only 1 item\n**And** the discount applies only to same-product pairs\n\n### Scenario 4: Discount stacking rules\n**Given** a cart with applicable discounts\n**When** multiple discount conditions are met\n**Then** the system applies the best single discount\n**And** discounts do not combine\n```\n\n### From Examples to Specifications\n\n```typescript\n// Example-driven specification\ninterface DiscountSpecification {\n  canApply(cart: ShoppingCart, customer: Customer): boolean;\n  calculateDiscount(cart: ShoppingCart, customer: Customer): Money;\n  priority: number;\n}\n\nclass WelcomeDiscountSpecification implements DiscountSpecification {\n  priority = 1;\n  \n  canApply(cart: ShoppingCart, customer: Customer): boolean {\n    return customer.orderCount === 0 && \n           cart.hasPromoCode('WELCOME10');\n  }\n  \n  calculateDiscount(cart: ShoppingCart, customer: Customer): Money {\n    const discount = cart.subtotal.multiply(0.10);\n    return discount.min(Money.fromAmount(20));\n  }\n}\n\nclass LoyaltyDiscountSpecification implements DiscountSpecification {\n  priority = 2;\n  \n  canApply(cart: ShoppingCart, customer: Customer): boolean {\n    return customer.orderCount > 5 && \n           cart.subtotal.greaterThan(Money.fromAmount(100));\n  }\n  \n  calculateDiscount(cart: ShoppingCart, customer: Customer): Money {\n    return cart.subtotal.multiply(0.15);\n  }\n}\n\nclass BogoSaleSpecification implements DiscountSpecification {\n  priority = 3;\n  \n  canApply(cart: ShoppingCart, customer: Customer): boolean {\n    return this.countEligiblePairs(cart) > 0;\n  }\n  \n  calculateDiscount(cart: ShoppingCart, customer: Customer): Money {\n    return this.calculatePairDiscounts(cart);\n  }\n}\n```\n\n## Gherkin Syntax\n\n```gherkin\nFeature: Shopping Cart Discounts\n\n  Background:\n    Given the discount engine is active\n    And promotional periods are correctly configured\n\n  Rule: Welcome discount for new customers\n\n    Example: First-time customer using welcome code\n      Given the customer has no previous orders\n      When they enter \"WELCOME10\" at checkout\n      Then the discount of 10% should be applied\n      And the maximum discount should be $20\n\n    Example: Welcome code not valid for returning customers\n      Given the customer has 3 previous orders\n      When they enter \"WELCOME10\" at checkout\n      Then the discount should not be applied\n      And an error message \"Welcome code only valid for new customers\" should be shown\n\n  Rule: Loyalty discount applies automatically\n\n    Example: Customer qualifies for loyalty discount\n      Given the customer has 10 previous orders\n      And their cart total is $150\n      When they proceed to checkout\n      Then a 15% discount should be automatically applied\n\n    Example: Cart below threshold doesn't qualify\n      Given the customer has 10 previous orders\n      And their cart total is $50\n      When they proceed to checkout\n      Then no automatic discount should be applied\n\n  Rule: Buy-one-get-one (BOGO) promotion\n\n    Example: Customer adds 2 identical items\n      Given a BOGO sale is active for \"Widget\"\n      And the customer adds 2 \"Widget\" items to cart\n      When they view the cart\n      Then they should be charged for only 1 item\n      And the discount should be $9.99 (price of one widget)\n\n    Example: Customer adds 3 identical items\n      Given a BOGO sale is active for \"Widget\"\n      And the customer adds 3 \"Widget\" items to cart\n      When they view the cart\n      Then they should be charged for 2 items\n      And the discount should be $9.99\n\n  Rule: Discount stacking is not allowed\n\n    Example: Multiple applicable discounts\n      Given the customer has 10 previous orders\n      And they enter \"WELCOME10\" at checkout\n      And their cart total is $200\n      When the discount is calculated\n      Then only the loyalty discount (15%) should be applied\n      And the welcome code should not be applied\n```\n\n## Example Mapping\n\n```markdown\n## Example Mapping Session\n\n### Question: How do discounts work?\n\n├── Business Rule: Welcome discount\n│   ├── Example: First-time customer with code → 10% off, max $20\n│   ├── Example: Returning customer with code → Invalid\n│   └── Example: No code entered → No welcome discount\n│\n├── Business Rule: Loyalty discount\n│   ├── Example: 10+ orders, cart $150+ → 15% off\n│   ├── Example: 10+ orders, cart $50 → No discount\n│   └── Example: 5 orders exactly → No discount\n│\n├── Business Rule: BOGO promotion\n│   ├── Example: 2 identical items → Charge for 1\n│   ├── Example: 3 identical items → Charge for 2\n│   ├── Example: Mixed items → No BOGO\n│   └── Example: BOGO with welcome code → BOGO applies\n│\n└── Business Rule: Single discount\n    ├── Example: Both welcome and loyalty apply → Best discount\n    ├── Example: BOGO with welcome code → BOGO applies\n    └── Example: All three conditions → Best of all\n```\n\n## Living Documentation\n\n```typescript\n// Living documentation that stays in sync\nimport { describe, it, beforeAll, afterAll } from 'vitest';\nimport { DiscountEngine } from './discount-engine';\nimport { ShoppingCart } from './shopping-cart';\nimport { Customer } from './customer';\n\n// This test suite IS the specification\n// Running it validates the specification\ndescribe('Discount Engine Specifications', () => {\n  let engine: DiscountEngine;\n  let database: TestDatabase;\n\n  beforeAll(async () => {\n    database = new TestDatabase();\n    await database.seed([\n      { type: 'product', sku: 'WIDGET', price: 9.99 },\n      { type: 'customer', id: 'cust_1', orderCount: 0 },\n      { type: 'customer', id: 'cust_2', orderCount: 10 }\n    ]);\n    \n    engine = new DiscountEngine(database);\n  });\n\n  afterAll(async () => {\n    await ShoppingCart.create()\n      .addItem('WIDGET', 1)\n      .addPromoCode('WELCOME10');\n    \n    const customer = database.customers.find('cust_1');\n    \n    const result =   "content": "# Event Sourcing\n\n## Overview\n\nEvent Sourcing is an architectural pattern where changes to the application state are stored as a sequence of events rather than maintaining just the current state. This approach provides a complete audit trail, enables temporal queries, and supports sophisticated business workflows.\n\n## Core Concept\n\n```\n┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐\n│                    EVENT SOURCING CONCEPT                                │\n├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤\n│                                                                      │\n│  TRADITIONAL APPROACH              EVENT SOURCING                         │\n│  ┌───────────────────┐           ┌───────────────────┐                    │\n│  │                   │           │                   │                    │\n│  │  Account: $1000  │           │  [Event Log]       │                    │\n│  │                   │           │                   │                    │\n│  │  UPDATE balance  │           │  AccountOpened     │                    │\n│  │  TO $800         │           │  → Initial: $1000  │                    │\n│  │                   │           │                   │                    │\n│  │                   │           │  Deposit           │                    │\n│  │  State is overwritten│         │  → +$500 = $1500   │                    │\n│  │                   │           │                   │                    │\n│  │                   │           │  Withdraw          │                    │\n│  │                   │           │  → -$500 = $1000   │                    │\n│  │                   │           │                   │                    │\n│  │                   │           │  Withdraw          │                    │\n│  │                   │           │  → -$200 = $800    │                    │\n│  │                   │           │                   │                    │\n│  │  Current: $800    │           │  Current: $800      │                    │\n│  │  History: LOST     │           │  History: COMPLETE  │                    │\n│  │                   │           │                   │                    │\n│  └───────────────────┘           └───────────────────┘                    │\n│                                                                      │\n│  KEY INSIGHT: Events are immutable facts; state is derived from events   │\n│                                                                      │\n└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘\n```\n\n## Event Sourcing Structure\n\n```typescript\n// Domain events are the source of truth\ninterface DomainEvent {\n  readonly eventId: string;\n  readonly aggregateId: string;\n  readonly aggregateType: string;\n  readonly eventType: string;\n  readonly payload: Record<string, unknown>;\n  readonly occurredAt: DateTime;\n  readonly version: number;\n}\n\n// Example events\nnamespace AccountEvents {\n  export class AccountOpened implements DomainEvent {\n    readonly eventType = 'AccountOpened';\n    \n    constructor(\n      readonly aggregateId: string,\n      readonly payload: {\n        ownerId: string;\n        initialBalance: number;\n        currency: string;\n      },\n      readonly occurredAt = DateTime.now()\n    ) {}\n  }\n\n  export class Deposited implements DomainEvent {\n    readonly eventType = 'Deposited';\n    \n    constructor(\n      readonly aggregateId: string,\n      readonly payload: {\n        amount: number;\n        depositId: string;\n        method: string;\n      },\n      readonly occurredAt = DateTime.now()\n    ) {}\n  }\n\n  export class Withdrawn implements DomainEvent {\n    readonly eventType = 'Withdrawn';\n    \n    constructor(\n      readonly aggregateId: string,\n      readonly payload: {\n        amount: number;\n        withdrawalId: string;\n        method: string;\n      },\n      readonly occurredAt = DateTime.now()\n    ) {}\n  }\n\n  export class AccountClosed implements DomainEvent {\n    readonly eventType = 'AccountClosed';\n    \n    constructor(\n      readonly aggregateId: string,\n      readonly payload: {\n        reason: string;\n        finalBalance: number;\n      },\n      readonly occurredAt = DateTime.now()\n    ) {}\n  }\n}\n```\n\n## Aggregate with Event Sourcing\n\n```typescript\n// Aggregate that derives state from events\nclass BankAccount implements AggregateRoot<AccountId> {\n  private _id: AccountId;\n  private _ownerId: string;\n  private _balance: number;\n  private _currency: string;\n  private _status: AccountStatus;\n  private _version: number;\n  private _uncommittedEvents: DomainEvent[];\n\n  // Private constructor - use factory methods\n  private constructor() {\n    this._uncommittedEvents = [];\n  }\n\n  // Apply event to state\n  private apply(event: DomainEvent): void {\n    switch (event.eventType) {\n      case 'AccountOpened':\n        const openEvent = event as AccountEvents.AccountOpened;\n        this._id = AccountId.fromString(event.aggregateId);\n        this._ownerId = openEvent.payload.ownerId;\n        this._balance = openEvent.payload.initialBalance;\n        this._currency = openEvent.payload.currency;\n        this._status = AccountStatus.ACTIVE;\n        this._version = 1;\n        break;\n\n      case 'Deposited':\n        const depositEvent = event as AccountEvents.Deposited;\n        this._balance += depositEvent.payload.amount;\n        this._version++;\n        break;\n\n      case 'Withdrawn':\n        const withdrawEvent = event as AccountEvents.Withdrawn;\n        this._balance -= withdrawEvent.payload.amount;\n        this._version++;\n        break;\n\n      case 'AccountClosed':\n        this._status = AccountStatus.CLOSED;\n        this._version++;\n        break;\n    }\n  }\n\n  // Replay events to build current state\n  static fromEvents(id: AccountId, events: DomainEvent[]): BankAccount {\n    const account = new BankAccount();\n    events.forEach(event => account.apply(event));\n    return account;\n  }\n\n  // Command: Deposit money\n  deposit(amount: number, method: string): void {\n    if (amount <= 0) {\n      throw new InvalidOperationError('Deposit amount must be positive');\n    }\n\n    const event = new AccountEvents.Deposited(\n      this._id.value,\n      {\n        amount,\n        depositId: DepositId.generate().value,\n        method\n      }\n    );\n\n    this.apply(event);\n    this._uncommittedEvents.push(event);\n  }\n\n  // Command: Withdraw money\n  withdraw(amount: number, method: string): void {\n    if (amount <= 0) {\n      throw new InvalidOperationError('Withdrawal amount must be positive');\n    }\n\n    if (this._balance < amount) {\n      throw new InsufficientFundsError('Insufficient balance');\n    }\n\n    const event = new AccountEvents.Withdrawn(\n      this._id.value,\n      {\n        amount,\n        withdrawalId: WithdrawalId.generate().value,\n        method\n      }\n    );\n\n    this.apply(event);\n    this._uncommittedEvents.push(event);\n  }\n\n  // Get uncommitted events and clear\n  getUncommittedEvents(): DomainEvent[] {\n    return [...this._uncommittedEvents];\n  }\n\n  clearUncommittedEvents(): void {\n    this._uncommittedEvents = [];\n  }\n}\n```\n\n## Event Store\n\n```typescript\n// Event Store interface\ninterface EventStore {\n  append(events: DomainEvent[]): Promise<void>;\n  getEvents(aggregateId: string, fromVersion?: number): Promise<DomainEvent[]>;\n  getAllEvents(since?: DateTime): Promise<DomainEvent[]>;\n  subscribe(eventType: string, handler: EventHandler): Promise<void>;\n}\n\n// Implementation using a database\nclass PostgresEventStore implements EventStore {\n  constructor(\n    private readonly pool: Pool,\n    private readonly eventPublisher: EventPublisher\n  ) {}\n\n  async append(events: DomainEvent[]): Promise<void> {\n    const client = await this.pool.connect();\n    \n    try {\n      await client.query('BEGIN');\n\n      for (const event of events) {\n        // Check for concurrency\n        const currentVersion = await this.getCurrentVersion(\n          client,\n          event.aggregateId\n        );\n\n        if (currentVersion !== event.version - 1) {\n          throw new ConcurrencyError(\n            `Expected version ${event.version - 1}, ` +\n            `but found ${currentVersion}`\n          );\n        }\n\n        // Store event\n        await client.query(\n          `INSERT INTO event_store \n           (aggregate_id, aggregate_type, event_type, payload, occurred_at, version)\n           VALUES ($1, $2, $3, $4, $5, $6)`,\n          [\n            event.aggregateId,\n            event.aggregateType,\n            event.eventType,\n            JSON.stringify(event.payload),\n            event.occurredAt,\n            event.version\n          ]\n        );\n      }\n\n      await client.query('COMMIT');\n\n      // Publish events for other consumers\n      for (const event of events) {\n        await this.eventPublisher.publish(event);\n      }\n    } catch (error) {\n      await client.query('ROLLBACK');\n      throw error;\n    } finally {\n      client.release();\n    }\n  }\n\n  private async getCurrentVersion(client: PoolClient, aggregateId: string): Promise<number> {\n    const result = await client.query(\n      'SELECT COALESCE(MAX(version), 0) FROM event_store WHERE aggregate_id = $1',\n      [aggregateId]\n    );\n    return parseInt(result.rows[0].coalesce);\n  }\n\n  async getEvents(aggregateId: string, fromVersion = 0): Promise<DomainEvent[]> {\n    const result = await this.pool.query(\n      `SELECT * FROM event_store \n       WHERE aggregate_id = $1 AND version > $2\n       ORDER BY version ASC`,\n      [aggregateId, fromVersion]\n    );\n\n    return result.rows.map(row => this.deserializeEvent(row));\n  }\n\n  private deserializeEvent(row: any): DomainEvent {\n    const payload = JSON.parse(row.payload);\n    \n    switch (row.event_type) {\n      case 'AccountOpened':\n        return new AccountEvents.AccountOpened(\n          row.aggregate_id,\n          payload\n        );\n      case 'Deposited':\n        return new AccountEvents.Deposited(\n          row.aggregate_id,\n          payload\n        );\n      case 'Withdrawn':\n        return new AccountEvents.Withdrawn(\n          row.aggregate_id,\n          payload\n        );\n      default:\n        throw new Error(`Unknown event type: ${row.event_type}`);\n    }\n  }\n}\n```\n\n## Projections (Read Models)\n\n```typescript\n// Project events to read models\ninterface Projection {\n  handles: string[];\n  apply(event: DomainEvent): Promise<void>;\n}\n\nclass AccountBalanceProjection implements Projection {\n  handles = ['AccountOpened', 'Deposited', 'Withdrawn', 'AccountClosed'];\n\n  constructor(private readonly readRepository: AccountBalanceRepository) {}\n\n  async apply(event: DomainEvent): Promise<void> {\n    switch (event.eventType) {\n      case 'AccountOpened':\n        await this.readRepository.create({\n          accountId: event.aggregateId,\n          balance: event.payload.initialBalance,\n          lastUpdated: DateTime.now()\n        });\n        break;\n\n      case 'Deposited':\n        await this.readRepository.updateBalance(\n          event.aggregateId,\n          event.payload.amount,\n          'ADD'\n        );\n        break;\n\n      case 'Withdrawn':\n        await this.readRepository.updateBalance(\n          event.aggregateId,\n          event.payload.amount,\n          'SUBTRACT'\n        );\n        break;\n\n      case 'AccountClosed':\n        await this.readRepository.markClosed(event.aggregateId);\n        break;\n    }\n  }\n}\n\n// Projection runner\nclass {
  "content": "# Test-Driven Development (TDD)\n\n## Core Concept\n\nTest-Driven Development (TDD) is a software development methodology that emphasizes writing tests before writing the implementation code. It follows a short, iterative development cycle known as the \"Red-Green-Refactor\" loop, where developers first write a failing test, then make the test pass with minimal code, and finally improve the code through refactoring while maintaining test coverage.\n\nTDD was popularized by Kent Beck in his 2003 book \"Test-Driven Development: By Example\" and has become a fundamental practice in agile software development. The methodology promotes better design, higher code quality, and increased confidence in the codebase by ensuring that all code is covered by automated tests from the start.\n\nThe core philosophy of TDD is simple but profound: write tests first, then write just enough code to make those tests pass, and continuously improve the design through refactoring. This approach forces developers to think about the desired behavior and interface of their code before implementation, leading to more modular, flexible, and maintainable software systems.\n\nTDD also serves as a design tool, helping developers clarify requirements and design interfaces before writing production code. By starting with a test, developers must consider how the code will be used, what inputs it will accept, and what outputs it should produce, leading to better-designed APIs and more focused, single-responsibility functions.\n\n---\n\n## The Red-Green-Refactor Cycle\n\n```\n┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐\n│                    TEST-DRIVEN DEVELOPMENT CYCLE                         │\n├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤\n│                                                                         │\n│    ┌──────────────┐         ┌──────────────┐         ┌──────────────┐  │\n│    │     RED      │ ──────► │    GREEN     │ ──────► │   REFACTOR   │  │\n│    │              │         │              │         │              │  │\n│    │ Write failing│         │ Write minimal│         │ Improve code │  │\n│    │ test first   │         │ code to pass │         │ design       │  │\n│    └──────────────┘         └──────────────┘         └──────────────┘  │\n│         ▲                         ▲                         ▲           │\n│         │                         │                         │           │\n│         │                         │                         │           │\n│         └─────────────────────────┴─────────────────────────┘           │\n│                           (Repeat)                                       │\n│                                                                         │\n└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘\n```\n\n### Red Phase: Write a Failing Test\n\nThe Red phase is where you write a test that describes the behavior you want to implement. This test should fail because the implementation doesn't exist yet. The test serves as a specification for the desired functionality and helps clarify what the code should do.\n\nKey principles for the Red phase:\n- Write a test that describes the behavior, not the implementation\n- The test should be small and focused on a single aspect of functionality\n- Run the test to confirm it fails (the test framework should show red)\n- Use descriptive test names that explain what the code should do\n- Start with the simplest possible test case\n\n### Green Phase: Make the Test Pass\n\nThe Green phase involves writing the minimal amount of code necessary to make the failing test pass. The goal is not to write perfect code but to get the test green as quickly as possible. This phase validates that your test correctly identifies the desired behavior.\n\nKey principles for the Green phase:\n- Write only the code needed to pass the test\n- Don't worry about optimal implementation or perfect design\n- You can use shortcuts, magic values, or temporary solutions\n- The focus is on correctness, not elegance\n- Once the test passes, you have verified behavior\n\n### Refactor Phase: Improve the Design\n\nThe Refactor phase is where you improve the code's structure, readability, and design while ensuring all tests continue to pass. This is your opportunity to clean up the code, remove duplication, and apply design principles without fear of breaking functionality.\n\nKey principles for the Refactor phase:\n- Improve code structure, naming, and organization\n- Extract methods, remove duplication, apply design patterns\n- Ensure all existing tests still pass after refactoring\n- Make small, incremental changes\n- Use the tests as a safety net for refactoring\n\n---\n\n## TDD in TypeScript with Jest\n\n```typescript\n// src/math/calculator.test.ts\nimport { Calculator } from  });\n\n  describe('multiply', () => {\n    it('should multiply two positive numbers correctly', () => {\n      const result = calculator.multiply(3, 4);\n      expect(result).toBe(12);\n    });\n\n decrement = () => {\n    if (count > minValue) {\n      setCount(count - 1);\n    }\n  };\n\n  const reset = () => {\n    setCount(initialValue);\n  };\n\n  return (\n    <div>\n      <h2>Count: {count}</h2>\n      <button onClick={increment}>Increment</button>\n      <button onClick={decrement}>Decrement</button>\n      <button onClick={reset}>Reset</button>\n    </div>\n  );\n};\n```\n\n---\n\n## TDD Best Practices\n\n### 1. Follow the First Rule of TDD\nThe first rule of TDD is: \"You must write a failing test before you write any production code.\" This ensures that every line of code is covered by a test and that you are solving the right problem.\n\n### 2. Keep Tests Fast\nFast tests enable rapid feedback and frequent refactoring. Aim for tests that run in milliseconds. Avoid slow operations like database calls, network requests, or file I/O in unit tests by using mocks and stubs.\n\n### 3. Write Isolated Tests\nEach test should be independent and not rely on the state from other tests. Use setup and teardown methods to ensure a clean state before each test runs.\n\n### 4. Use Descriptive Test Names\nTest names should clearly describe what behavior is being tested. Use the pattern: \"should [expected behavior] when [condition]\". This makes tests act as documentation for your code.\n\n### 5. Test Behavior, Not Implementation\nFocus on testing the public interface and expected behavior rather than internal implementation details. This allows you to refactor the implementation without breaking tests.\n\n### 6. Follow the Triangulation Rule\nWhen you're unsure about the implementation, write multiple tests with different inputs to triangulate the correct solution. This helps you understand the requirements better.\n\n### 7. Apply the \"F.I.R.S.T.\" Principles\n- **Fast**: Tests should be fast to enable quick feedback.\n- **Independent**: Tests should not depend on each other.\n- **Repeatable**: Tests should produce the same result every time.\n- **Self-Validating**: Tests should have a clear pass/fail result.\n- **Timely**: Tests should be written before the production code.\n\n### 8. Use the \"One Assertion per Test\" Guideline\nWhile not a strict rule, having one assertion per test makes it easier to understand what failed and why. However, multiple assertions that test the same behavior can be acceptable.\n\n### 9. Maintain Test Code Quality\nTests are code too. Apply the same coding standards, refactoring practices, and design principles to test code as you do to production code.\n\n### 10. Don't Skip Refactoring\nThe refactoring phase is essential for maintaining code quality. Don't skip it even when under time pressure. The safety net of tests makes refactoring safe and valuable.\n\n---\n\n## TDD Anti-Patterns\n\n### 1. Testing Implementation Details\nTesting private methods, internal state, or implementation-specific details makes tests brittle. When you refactor the implementation, tests break even though the behavior hasn't changed.\n\n### 2. Large Test Setup\nTests with extensive setup code are hard to understand and maintain. Extract common setup into helper methods or use test data builders.\n\n### 3. Brittle Tests\nTests that break with every small change indicate they are testing the wrong thing. Focus on behavior rather than implementation.\n\n### 4. Ignoring Test Failures\nNever ignore a failing test. It could indicate a regression or that the test is no longer valid. Either fix the code or update the test.\n\n### 5. Testing Third-Party Code\nDon't write tests for third-party libraries or frameworks. Trust that they have their own tests. Only test your integration with them.\n\n### 6. Over-Mocked Tests\nToo many mocks can make tests useless. Focus on mocking boundaries (external services, databases) but test the interaction between your objects directly.\n\n### 7. Slow Tests\nTests that take too long discourage frequent execution. Keep unit tests fast by avoiding real I/O, databases, or networks.\n\n### 8. Inconsistent Naming\nPoorly named tests make it hard to understand what behavior is being tested. Use descriptive names that explain the expected behavior.\n\n### 9. Duplicate Test Code\nRepeated setup or assertions across tests indicate an opportunity for extraction. Use helper methods, fixtures, or parameterized tests.\n\n### 10. Testing Trivial Code\nDon't waste time testing trivial getters/setters or one-line functions that can't possibly fail. Focus on complex business logic.\n\n---\n\n## TDD in AI-Assisted Development\n\nWhen working with AI assistants for TDD, follow these practices:\n\n### 1. Provide Clear Requirements First\nBefore asking the AI to generate code, provide clear specifications of the expected behavior. The AI can then write tests that match these requirements.\n\n### 2. Use the AI to Generate Test Cases\nAsk the AI to help identify edge cases and generate comprehensive test scenarios that you might not have considered.\n\n### 3. Leverage AI for Refactoring\nAI assistants can help identify refactoring opportunities and ensure that refactored code maintains the same behavior and passes all tests.\n\n### 4. Combine with BDD\nUse AI to help translate natural language requirements into Gherkin scenarios or Given-When-Then test structures.\n\n### 5. AI as a TDD Partner\nTreat the AI as a TDD partner: describe what you want to test, have it write the test, then implement the code together.\n\n### 6. Validate AI-Generated Tests\nAlways review and understand AI-generated tests. They should clearly express the intended behavior and not contain logical errors.\n\n### 7. Use AI for Property-Based Testing\nAI can help identify properties and invariants that should hold across all inputs, making property-based testing more effective.\n\n---\n\n## Advanced TDD Patterns\n\n### 1. Transformation Priority Premise\nKent Beck's Transformation Priority Premise suggests a order of transformations to apply when moving from a failing test to a passing test:\n\n```\n( () -> () )                           // Empty test\n↓\n( {assertion} -> {return constant} )  // Return a constant\n↓\n{return constant} -> {return input}   // Return the input\n↓\n{return input} -> {return input + 1}  // Apply a simple transformation\n...\n```\n\n### 2. London School vs. Classic TDD\n- **London School (Mockist)**: Focus on isolating units with heavy mocking, testing interactions between objects.\n- ** Classic TDD (Detroit School)**: Focus on testing observable behavior, using mocks sparingly.\n\n### 3. Outside-In TDD (London School)\nStart from the outside (user interface or API) and work inward, using \"triangulation\" to define the inner components.\n\n### 4. Isolation Paths\nUse different testing strategies for different types of code:\n- **Pure functions**: Easy to test, no mocking needed\n- **Stateful objects**: Test state transitions\n- **Collaborative objects**: Test interactions with mocks\n- **Side effects**: Test through contracts and boundaries\n\n### 5. The London School Approach\nThe London School emphasizes:\n- Testing interactions between objects with mocks\n- Following a strict outside-in development\n- Defining collaboration before implementation\n- Using mock objects to drive design\n\n### 6. {
  "content": "# Behavior-Driven Development (BDD)\n\n## Core Concept\n\nBehavior-Driven Development (BDD) is an Agile software development methodology that extends Test-Driven Development by emphasizing collaboration between technical and non-technical stakeholders. BDD focuses on defining the behavior of a system from the user's perspective using natural language constructs that can be understood by both developers and business users.\n\nBDD was created by Dan North in the early 2000s as a response to the challenges he encountered while teaching TDD. The key insight was that tests written in technical code (like JUnit) were inaccessible to business stakeholders, leading to miscommunication and misalignment between what was built and what was actually needed.\n\nThe core innovation of BDD is the use of a domain-specific language (DSL) called Gherkin, which allows you to write specifications in natural language that can be executed as tests. This creates a bridge between business requirements and technical implementation, ensuring that everyone shares a common understanding of the system's behavior.\n\nBDD promotes the principle of \"Given-When-Then\" as a structured format for expressing examples of system behavior. This structure helps teams think through scenarios, identify edge cases, and create executable specifications that serve as both documentation and tests.\n\n---\n\n## The BDD Workflow\n\n```\n┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐\n│                    BDD DEVELOPMENT WORKFLOW                              │\n├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤\n│                                                                         │\n│  ┌─────────────┐    ┌─────────────┐    ┌─────────────┐    ┌─────────┐  │\n│  │   DISCOVER  │───►│   FORMALIZE │───►│  AUTOMATE   │───►│IMPLEMENT│  │\n│  │             │    │             │    │             │    │         │  │\n│  │  Collaborate│    │  Write      │    │  Generate   │    │  Write  │  │\n│  │  on examples│    │  scenarios  │    │  test code  │    │  code   │  │\n│  └─────────────┘    └─────────────┘    └─────────────┘    └─────────┘  │\n│         │                  │                  │                  │      │\n│         ▼                  ▼                  ▼                  ▼      │\n│  ┌─────────────┐    ┌─────────────┐    ┌─────────────┐    ┌─────────┐  │\n│  │   Example   │    │   Gherkin   │    │   Step      │    │  Pass   │  │\n│  │   Mapping   │    │   Scenarios │    │ Definitions │    │  Tests  │  │\n│  └─────────────┘    └─────────────┘    └─────────────┘    └─────────┘  │\n│                                                                         │\n└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘\n```\n\n### Step 1: Discovery\nEngage with stakeholders to understand the desired behavior of the system. Use collaborative techniques like Example Mapping to identify scenarios and examples that illustrate the expected behavior.\n\n### Step 2: Formalize\nConvert the discovered examples into formal Gherkin scenarios using the Given-When-Then structure. These scenarios serve as both specifications and executable tests.\n\n### Step 3: Automate\nUse a BDD framework like Cucumber, SpecFlow, or Behave to generate step definitions from the Gherkin scenarios. These step definitions will be implemented to make the scenarios pass.\n\n### Step 4: Implement\nWrite the production code that implements the behavior described in the scenarios. Run the scenarios to verify that the implementation meets the specified behavior.\n\n---\n\n## Gherkin Syntax Reference\n\nGherkin is a domain-specific language that allows you to write human-readable specifications. It uses a simple, line-oriented syntax that can be understood by non-technical stakeholders.\n\n```\nFeature: Search functionality\n  As a user\n  I want to search for products\n  So that I can find the user enters \"xyz123nonexistent\" in the search box\n    And clicks the search button\n    Then a \"No results found\" message should be displayed\n    And the results count should be 0\n\n  Scenario Outline: Search with various products\n    When the user enters \"<product_name>\" in the search box\n    And clicks the search button\n    Then results should be displayed\n    And the results should contain \"<product_name>\"\n\n    Examples:\n      | product_name |\n      | smartphone   |\n      | headphones   |\n      | smartwatch   |\n```\n\n### Gherkin Keywords\n\n| Keyword | Purpose | Description |\n|---------|---------|-------------|\n| `Feature` | Grouping | Groups related scenarios into a single feature |\n| `Background` | Precondition | Defines steps that run before    }\n//   }\n// }\n```\n\n---\n\n## BDD Best Practices\n\n### 1. Write Scenarios from the User's Perspective\nFocus on what the user wants to achieve, not on technical implementation details. Use user-focused language and avoid exposing internal mechanics in scenarios.\n\n### 2. Keep Scenarios Short and Focused\nEach scenario should test one specific behavior. If you find yourself with many steps, consider splitting the scenario into multiple smaller scenarios.\n\n### 3. Use Concrete Examples\nAvoid abstract descriptions. Use specific, realistic examples that demonstrate the expected behavior. This makes the scenarios more meaningful and easier to understand.\n\n### 4. Avoid Technical Language in Scenarios\nBusiness stakeholders should be able to read and understand the scenarios without technical knowledge. Keep the language business-oriented.\n\n### 5. Use Background Wisely\nThe Background section is useful for setting up common preconditions, but avoid overusing it. If a precondition is specific to a scenario, keep it in the Scenario.\n\n### 6. Use Scenario Outlines for Data-Driven Tests\nWhen you have multiple similar scenarios with different data, use Scenario Outline with Examples tables instead of repeating similar scenarios.\n\n### 7. Maintain the Single Source of Truth\nBDD scenarios should be the authoritative specification. All development should trace back to scenarios, and scenarios should be kept up to date.\n\n### 8. Involve All Stakeholders\nBDD requires collaboration between developers, testers, business analysts, and product owners. Ensure all perspectives are included in the discovery process.\n\n### 9. Treat Scenarios as Living Documentation\nScenarios should be maintained and updated as the system evolves. They serve as both tests and documentation, so keep them accurate.\n\n### 10. Don't Test Implementation in Scenarios\nFocus on observable behavior, not on how something is implemented. This allows for refactoring without breaking scenarios.\n\n---\n\n## BDD Anti-Patterns\n\n### 1. Technical Scenarios\nScenarios that describe implementation details instead of user behavior make BDD less effective for communication with business stakeholders.\n\n### 2. Scenarios as Test Scripts\nWriting scenarios that are simply recorded steps without business value defeats the purpose of BDD as a specification tool.\n\n### 3. Missing the \"Then\" Part\nScenarios must have assertions (Then steps) that verify the expected outcome. Without them, scenarios don't validate behavior.\n\n### 4. Overly Complex Step Definitions\nIf step definitions are complex, it indicates that either the scenario is too detailed or the implementation needs better abstractions.\n\n### 5. Ignoring Failing Scenarios\nFailing scenarios should be treated as bugs in the specification or implementation. Ignoring them leads to technical debt.\n\n### 6. Gherkin as Just Another Test Framework\nUsing Gherkin without the collaborative discovery process misses the main value of BDD. BDD is about communication, not just automation.\n\n### 7. Scenario Proliferation\nHaving too many scenarios for simple functionality indicates that scenarios may be testing implementation details rather than behavior.\n\n### 8. No Business Involvement\nIf business stakeholders don't participate in writing or reviewing scenarios, BDD loses its effectiveness as a communication tool.\n\n### 9. Hard-Coded Data in Scenarios\nUsing specific values that don't represent realistic scenarios makes tests less meaningful. Use representative example data.\n\n### 10. Scenarios Without Acceptance Criteria\nVague scenarios that don't clearly define what constitutes success lead to misunderstanding and rework.\n\n---\n\n## BDD in AI-Assisted Development\n\nWhen working with AI assistants for BDD, follow these practices:\n\n### 1. Use AI for Scenario Generation\nProvide the AI with user stories or requirements and ask it to generate Gherkin scenarios. Review and refine the scenarios for accuracy.\n\n### 2. AI as a BDD Coach\nAsk the AI to review your Gherkin scenarios for clarity, completeness, and adherence to BDD best practices.\n\n### 3. Automate Step Definition Generation\nAfter writing scenarios, ask the AI to generate the initial step definition stubs that you can then implement.\n\n### 4. Combine with Example Mapping\nUse AI to help facilitate Example Mapping sessions by generating examples and scenarios from natural language requirements.\n\n### 5. AI for Edge Case Discovery\nAsk the AI to identify edge cases and unusual scenarios that you might have missed in your BDD scenarios.\n\n### 6. Translate Domain Knowledge\nUse AI to help translate domain-specific language and business rules into clear, executable Gherkin scenarios.\n\n### 7. Maintain Consistency\nUse AI to ensure consistent terminology and structure across all scenarios in a feature file.\n\n### 8. Documentation Generation\nAsk AI to generate human-readable documentation from Gherkin scenarios for stakeholders who prefer plain English.\n\n---\n\n## BDD Framework Comparison\n\n| Framework | Language | Key Features | Best For |\n|-----------|----------|--------------|----------|\n| **Cucumber** | Multi-language | Large community, extensive integrations | Cross-team collaboration |\n| **SpecFlow** | C#/.NET | Visual Studio integration, SpecFlow+ | .NET ecosystems |\n| **Behave** | Python | Simple setup, Pythonic | Python teams |\n| **Jest BDD** | JavaScript | Integrated with Jest, great for React | JavaScript/TypeScript |\n| **Gauge** | Multi-language | Multi-modal, Markdown-based | Rapid test development |\n| **Concordion** | Java | HTML-based specifications | Java teams wanting rich reports |\n\n---\n\n## References and Further Reading\n\n1. Created by Gojko Adzic, Impact Mapping helps teams answer the fundamental question of \"why are we building this?\" by tracing the causal chain from organizational goals to specific deliverables.\n\nThe technique addresses a common problem in software projects: starting with a list of features or user stories without clearly understanding the underlying business objectives. This often leads to feature bloat, wasted effort, and projects that fail to deliver meaningful value even when delivered on time and within budget.\n\nImpact Mapping provides a visual framework for exploring and documenting the connections between business goals, actors, impacts, and deliverables. By making these connections explicit, teams can make better-informed decisions about scope, prioritize more effectively, and avoid building features that don't contribute to organizational goals.\n\nThe key insight of Impact Mapping is that every feature or user story should trace back to a specific business goal, and every business goal should be supported by specific impacts from specific actors. If you cannot trace a feature through this chain, it should be questioned or eliminated.\n\n---\n\n## Impact Mapping Structure\n\n```\n┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐\n│                      IMPACT MAPPING TREE                                 │\n├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤\n│                                                                         │\n│                         ┌─────────────────┐                              │\n│                         │      GOAL       │                              │\n│                         │                 │                              │\n│                         │  Why are we     │                              │\n│                         │  doing this? This should be something the organization wants to achieve, such as increasing revenue, reducing costs, improving customer satisfaction, or entering a new market.\n\n### Actor (Who)\nActors are the individuals or groups who can help achieve the goal.
