# Context Engineering: The Invisible Discipline Keeping AI Agents from Drowning in Their Own Memory

[Juan C Olamendy](https://medium.com/@juanc.olamendy?source=post_page---byline--c0283ca6a954---------------------------------------)

16 min read

·

3 days ago

--

Listen

Share

Press enter or click to view image in full size

Your AI agent just crashed. Not because of a bug in the code. Not because the model failed. But because you fed it too much information.

**Every LLM has a memory limit, but most engineers treat it like infinite storage.**

They dump entire conversation histories, tool outputs, and workflow logs into each prompt, watching costs explode and performance crater.

The result? Agents that hallucinate, contradict themselves, and fail at exactly the wrong moment.

In fact, it often means worse performance, higher costs, and complete system failure.

**Context engineering fixes this.**

It’s the discipline of strategically managing what information your AI actually sees — using pruning, summarization, and isolation techniques to keep agents sharp, fast, and cost-effective.

This article explores context engineering — what it is, why it matters, and how to master the techniques that separate production-grade AI systems from prototype failures.

## What Is Context Engineering?

Context engineering represents the discipline of managing, curating, reducing, and controlling the information you send to large language models.

The field emerged from a fundamental constraint: LLMs have fixed context windows with hard token limits. When you build agent systems that make multiple tool calls, maintain conversation history, and process complex workflows, the naive approach of aggregating everything into the prompt quickly exhausts available space.

The basic agent implementations can generate hundreds of thousands of tokens after just several rounds of tool calls and message exchanges. This isn’t just expensive — it directly impacts the LLM’s ability to follow instructions accurately. Model quality degrades as context grows, a phenomenon researchers call “context rot.”

Context engineering addresses three fundamental challenges in LLM applications.

First, it tackles efficiency by optimizing context to reduce latency and inference costs.

Second, it preserves performance by preventing long, un-curated context from degrading model output.

Third, it enables scalability by making it practical for production agents to execute dozens or hundreds of tool calls per run.

Think of context engineering as the memory management system for AI agents. Just as operating systems can’t load every file into RAM simultaneously, agent systems can’t dump every piece of historical information into each LLM call. You need strategic decisions about what to keep, what to compress, and what to discard.

## Why Context Engineering Matters

The stakes of context engineering extend far beyond theoretical concerns. Production AI systems live or die based on how they manage context.

Consider an enterprise agent that helps developers debug code across a large codebase. Without proper context management, the agent might reference outdated file versions, lose track of implemented fixes, or hallucinate solutions based on irrelevant historical context.

Context rot represents the most insidious challenge in long-running agent workflows. As the context window fills with information, the model loses focus and makes mistakes even when technically staying within token limits.

Research from Anthropic and other AI labs confirms that model quality degrades well before you hit the theoretical maximum context window. A model with a million-token context window might perform optimally only in the first 100,000 tokens of actual usage.

Cost considerations create another compelling argument for context engineering. Every token you send to an LLM incurs inference costs. When your agent makes 50 tool calls and you naively append every result to the context, you’re paying to process massive amounts of information repeatedly — most of it irrelevant to the current task. Production systems that ignore context engineering quickly become cost-prohibitive at scale.

Latency represents the third critical factor. Users expect responsive AI interactions, but processing 500,000 tokens takes significantly longer than processing 5,000 tokens. Context engineering techniques reduce latency by ensuring the model receives only essential information. This speed improvement directly translates to better user experience and higher system throughput.

The scalability implications become clear when examining real-world agent platforms. Manus, a production agent system, routinely handles workflows requiring 50+ tool calls per run. Without aggressive context engineering — including pruning, summarization, and offloading — such systems would be impossible to operate economically. Claude Code and similar development tools rely heavily on context summarization to maintain coherent tool call histories over extended coding sessions.

## Core Context Engineering Techniques

Mastering context engineering requires understanding six foundational techniques. Each addresses different aspects of the context management problem, and production systems typically combine multiple approaches.

## 1\. Pruning: Strategic Information Removal

Pruning forms the foundation of context reduction strategies. This technique systematically removes older, less relevant, or redundant information from the context window when preparing each LLM input prompt. The goal is straightforward: keep only essential, high-value content so the model can focus its full capacity on recent and relevant details.

Every LLM operates within a fixed token limit called the context window size. When your conversation history or agent workflow generates more tokens than this limit allows, information must be discarded. Pruning helps you make intelligent decisions about what stays and what goes. Without pruning, you either crash when hitting the limit or allow the system to arbitrarily truncate context in ways that destroy coherence.

The simplest pruning implementations use chronological rules — removing the oldest exchanges, tool call results, or messages first. For example, you might configure your system to always retain only the last N messages. This approach works well for straightforward conversational agents where recent context matters most. However, it falls short in complex workflows where older information might remain critical to ongoing tasks.

Advanced pruning employs heuristic-based removal strategies. You can drop messages containing confirmations, casual conversation, or completed step notifications while preserving instructions, open tasks, and unresolved issues. Priority-based pruning assigns importance scores to different message types — with instruction steps scoring higher than confirmations or chit-chat — and removes the lowest-priority content first.

Semantic pruning represents the most sophisticated approach. These systems analyze message content and remove anything semantically redundant, off-topic, or already incorporated into summaries. Semantic search identifies which passages or tool results prove most relevant to the current query or task. This technique requires more computational overhead but produces superior results in complex scenarios.

Pruning should trigger automatically when the context window approaches a threshold. Common implementations activate pruning at 80–95% of maximum token size, or after specific agent actions like tool calls or workflow step completions. This automatic triggering ensures consistent context management without requiring manual intervention.

Modern systems pair pruning with summarization for maximum effectiveness. Before dropping content, they compress long passages into short, semantically-rich summaries. After five conversation turns, for example, the agent might summarize steps 1–3 and prune their raw messages, retaining only the summary plus the latest two turns. This combination preserves essential information while dramatically reducing token count.

Consider a practical example where an agent queries five different tools across multiple turns. Without pruning, the system sends the entire transcript at each turn, accumulating tool results A through E. With pruning, after the fifth turn, the system keeps only the most recent turns (3, 4, and 5) that contain the active instruction and latest results. It summarizes results from the first two turns (“Initial data processed”) and drops the raw tool outputs for A and B. The result: a focused prompt that maintains task continuity while using a fraction of the tokens.

## 2\. Summarization: Intelligent Compression

Summarization compresses long message chains or interaction histories into concise summaries that preserve semantic relevance.

This technique reduces cost and mitigates context rot while maintaining the information necessary for the model to perform effectively. Unlike pruning, which removes information entirely, summarization transforms verbose content into compact representations.

Hierarchical and iterative summarization frameworks provide the most robust approach. These systems break long contexts into logical chunks, summarize each chunk independently, then potentially summarize the summaries for deeply nested workflows.

Modern agent frameworks like LangChain, Claude Code, and Manus prioritize summarization at natural break points in workflows — after completing discrete tasks, reaching decision points, or transitioning between workflow phases.

Implementation typically involves triggering summarization when context reaches a threshold, commonly 50% of the available window. This proactive approach prevents the context from ever reaching dangerous fullness levels. Some systems also trigger summarization when starting new tasks, ensuring each major phase begins with a clean, compressed history.

The mechanics of summarization rely on the LLM itself. You send the accumulated history to the model with instructions to produce a concise summary capturing key facts, decisions, and unresolved issues. This summary then replaces the original verbose content in subsequent prompts. The key challenge lies in crafting summarization prompts that preserve critical details while achieving meaningful compression.

Effective summarization instructions specify what to preserve: open tasks, decisions made, important facts discovered, and unresolved issues or questions. They also specify what to exclude: casual conversation, confirmations, intermediate steps that led to decisions, and information already acted upon. This guidance ensures summaries remain actionable rather than merely descriptive.

Rolling summarization represents an advanced pattern where summaries themselves get updated and re-compressed over time. As new interactions occur, the system can either append to existing summaries or regenerate them entirely.

This approach enables indefinite conversation or workflow length while maintaining bounded context size. The trade-off involves potential information loss in the compression process, making it crucial to carefully tune what gets preserved.

## 3\. Offloading: External Memory Management

Offloading moves detailed data and results outside the context window into external memory systems. Rather than keeping everything in the prompt, you store tool results, intermediate outputs, and historical data in file systems, databases, or knowledge bases. Only references, summaries, or specifically needed information gets sent to the model.

This technique proves essential for long-term state management and tasks involving massive datasets. When an agent processes thousands of documents, you can’t include all document contents in every prompt. Instead, you store documents externally and retrieve only relevant portions when needed. Offloading enables agents to work with data well beyond the model’s token limit while maintaining efficiency.

Implementation requires careful architecture design. You establish an external store — perhaps a vector database, file system, or structured database — where the agent saves detailed outputs immediately after generation. The agent maintains references to this stored data in its context, using identifiers or short summaries. When detailed information becomes necessary, the agent queries the external store, retrieves relevant content, and includes it in the next prompt.

The atomic tool pattern complements offloading strategies effectively. Rather than binding many specialized tools directly to the agent — which bloats system prompts with tool descriptions — you provide a small set of versatile, general-purpose tools. A bash tool or filesystem tool enables the agent to run scripts or commands accomplishing diverse tasks without increasing prompt size for each capability. The agent stores complex tool outputs externally and retrieves them through these atomic tools as needed.

Consider an agent processing 1,000 emails as a concrete example. Without offloading, you’d attempt to include all email content in the context — clearly impossible. With offloading, the agent processes each email, generates summaries, and stores full email contents in an external database indexed by email ID.

The context contains only the summaries and reference IDs. When a user asks about a specific email, the agent queries the database using the ID, retrieves the full content, then sends that specific content to the LLM for analysis.

Offloading also supports iterative refinement workflows. An agent might generate a draft document, store it externally, then later retrieve and revise it based on new information or feedback. This pattern avoids keeping large document contents in context while enabling sophisticated multi-stage workflows. The external storage serves as working memory, complementing the LLM’s context window for active processing.

## 4\. Atomic Tools: Simplified Tool Architectures

The atomic tool pattern addresses prompt bloat caused by extensive tool definitions. Rather than equipping agents with dozens of specialized tools — each requiring detailed descriptions in the system prompt — you provide a few general-purpose, single-responsibility tools with clear, narrow scopes. This approach reduces the token overhead of tool descriptions while maintaining agent capabilities.

Atomic tools follow the Unix philosophy: do one thing well. Each tool handles a specific, precisely defined task with minimal ambiguity. A file read tool reads files. A web search tool searches the web. A bash execution tool runs shell commands. By composing these simple tools, agents accomplish complex tasks without the overhead of specialized tool combinations.

The benefits extend beyond mere token savings. Atomic tools reduce debugging complexity because each tool’s behavior is predictable and contained. They improve maintainability since tool definitions remain simple and stable. They also enhance orchestration by enabling clean data flow — output from one atomic tool can be directly fed as input to another without transformation.

Leading agent platforms demonstrate this pattern effectively. Replit, Cursor, and LangChain agents feature highly atomic tool definitions. Rather than a “analyze\_and\_fix\_code” tool, they provide separate “read\_file,” “analyze\_code,” and “write\_file” tools that the agent chains together. This granularity gives agents flexibility while keeping system prompts manageable.

Implementation requires careful tool design focused on clear interfaces. Each tool should have explicit input schemas and predictable output formats. Documentation should be minimal but complete, specifying exactly what the tool does and what it returns. Resist the temptation to create convenience tools that bundle multiple operations — these inevitably lead to ambiguity and prompt bloat.

The atomic tool pattern pairs naturally with offloading strategies. A general-purpose file system tool enables the agent to save and retrieve data from external storage without needing specialized persistence tools. A bash tool allows the agent to invoke any command-line utility without explicit tool definitions for each utility. This combination provides maximum flexibility with minimal prompt overhead.

## 5\. Context Isolation: Sub-Agent Architectures

Context isolation uses sub-agent architectures to handle token-heavy or logically isolated subtasks. Rather than forcing the main agent to process everything in a single context window, you spawn dedicated sub-agents for focused missions. Each sub-agent receives fresh, minimal context, performs its specific task, and returns only a condensed output to the main agent.

This technique addresses several challenges simultaneously. It isolates complexity, preventing cross-task context pollution. It keeps each task’s context window uncluttered and focused. It enables parallelization when multiple subtasks can run concurrently. It also supports specialization — different sub-agents can use different system prompts or even different models optimized for their specific tasks.

The main agent acts as an orchestrator in this pattern. It receives user requests, breaks them into logical subtasks, spawns appropriate sub-agents, and synthesizes their results into coherent responses. The main agent never sees the detailed interaction history of its sub-agents — only their final outputs or summaries. This strict isolation prevents the main agent’s context from becoming polluted with subtask details.

Claude Code demonstrates this pattern effectively. When a developer requests a complex code refactoring, the main agent might spawn sub-agents for analyzing dependencies, generating new implementations, updating tests, and verifying correctness. Each sub-agent works in isolation with only the context needed for its specific subtask. The main agent receives brief summaries and makes decisions about how to proceed based on these high-level results.

Implementation requires establishing clear communication protocols between agents. The main agent must provide sufficient context for sub-agents to operate independently. Sub-agents must return results in formats the main agent can easily process. You need error handling for sub-agent failures that doesn’t propagate confusion back to the main agent’s context.

Multi-agent frameworks like LangGraph provide built-in support for this pattern. They handle sub-agent lifecycle management, context isolation, and result aggregation. Without these frameworks, you’ll need to implement the orchestration logic carefully to maintain clean context boundaries and prevent information leakage between agents.

The isolation pattern also supports recursive decomposition. A sub-agent can itself spawn sub-sub-agents for further specialized tasks. This hierarchical approach enables handling arbitrary workflow complexity while maintaining clean, focused context at each level. The key is ensuring each level only sees appropriate abstraction — higher levels see summaries, lower levels see details.

## 6\. Conservative Context Management

Conservative context management recognizes that the technical maximum context window doesn’t equal optimal usage. Model performance degrades — through context rot — well before you hit token limits. This technique emphasizes selectivity and dynamic adjustment in how much context you actually provide to the model.

Research consistently shows that LLMs perform most accurately within their “effective” window, which typically runs much smaller than the technical maximum. A model advertising a million-token context might deliver best results in the first 50,000–100,000 tokens. Beyond that, accuracy drops, hallucinations increase, and instruction following degrades even though the model technically accepts more input.

Conservative strategies start fresh frequently. Rather than accumulating context indefinitely, reset after completing major tasks or when reaching 50% of the available window. This might mean starting new conversation threads, spawning new agent instances, or triggering comprehensive summarization that essentially reboots the context. The goal is never allowing context to grow large enough that quality suffers.

Query-aware contextualization provides another conservative technique. Dynamically adjust what context you include based on the specific query or task at hand. Not every question needs the full conversation history. Many tasks benefit more from targeted, relevant context than from comprehensive but noisy historical information. This selective approach keeps context lean and focused.

Breaking down complex tasks into smaller subtasks naturally supports conservative context management. Rather than attempting a massive operation in one extended context window, decompose it into discrete steps, each with its own fresh context. This approach aligns well with sub-agent isolation patterns and ensures each step receives optimal attention.

Implementation involves monitoring context usage and establishing triggers for intervention. Track token counts in real-time. Set alerts or automatic actions when reaching specific thresholds — perhaps 40% for a warning and 60% for automatic summarization. Make context window management a first-class concern in your system architecture rather than an afterthought.

Position critical information strategically within your prompts. Research shows models pay most attention to the beginning and end of context windows. Place key instructions and essential context in these positions. Consider the “lost in the middle” phenomenon where information buried in the middle of long contexts gets overlooked. Structure your prompts to work with this limitation rather than fighting it.

## Real-World Applications and Examples

Production AI systems validate these context engineering principles through demonstrated success. Examining real-world implementations reveals how companies combine multiple techniques to achieve reliable, cost-effective agent systems.

Manus, a production agent platform, routinely executes workflows requiring 50+ tool calls per run. Their system employs aggressive pruning, removing tool outputs immediately after the agent acknowledges and acts on them. They use rolling summarization at workflow phase boundaries, compressing completed steps into brief summaries. They offload detailed tool results to structured storage, keeping only task-critical information in active context. Without this sophisticated context engineering, their platform would be economically unviable.

Claude Code implements hierarchical summarization in tool call histories. When developers engage in extended coding sessions involving dozens of file edits, code analyses, and test runs, the system continuously compresses historical context. It preserves the current file state and recent operations while summarizing earlier changes. This enables developers to work through complex refactoring over hours without the agent losing coherence or requiring manual context resets.

Research platforms demonstrate context engineering principles through empirical results. Anthropic’s research on context rot confirms that model quality degrades with context length, recommending aggressive compaction and summarization. The company’s documentation suggests starting fresh contexts regularly rather than attempting to maintain indefinitely long conversation threads. These findings inform the design of production systems across the industry.

Enterprise implementations often combine all six techniques we’ve discussed. Consider a customer service agent handling complex technical support cases. It uses pruning to drop acknowledged messages and completed troubleshooting steps. It employs summarization to compress long diagnostic logs and conversation histories. It offloads customer account details and product documentation to external databases, retrieving only relevant sections. It uses atomic tools for ticket management, database queries, and knowledge base searches. It spawns sub-agents for specialized tasks like parsing error logs or generating solution summaries. And it maintains conservative context usage by resetting after resolving each case.

The performance gains from proper context engineering prove substantial. Teams report 10x reductions in token usage through pruning and summarization alone. Latency improvements of 50–70% emerge from keeping contexts lean and focused. Cost reductions of similar magnitude make previously impractical workflows economically viable. Most importantly, accuracy and reliability improve dramatically when models work within their effective context windows.

## Best Practices for Context Engineering

Implementing effective context engineering requires following established best practices while adapting to your specific use case. Start by establishing clear metrics for context management success.

Track token usage per interaction, monitoring both average and peak consumption. Measure model performance across different context sizes to identify your effective window. Monitor costs directly tied to context length to understand economic implications. Assess user experience metrics like response latency and accuracy as context grows. These metrics guide optimization decisions and validate improvements.

Design for context engineering from the beginning rather than retrofitting it later. Build context tracking into your agent architecture from the first prototype. Establish clear patterns for when pruning, summarization, and offloading occur. Create abstractions that make context management decisions explicit and testable. This architectural approach prevents context management from becoming an afterthought that’s painful to add later.

Test rigorously across different context scenarios. Evaluate your agent with minimal context, moderate context, and near-maximum context. Verify that pruning and summarization preserve essential information. Confirm that offloading and retrieval mechanisms work reliably. Test edge cases like when summarization itself might introduce errors or when pruning removes critical data. Comprehensive testing catches context management bugs before they reach production.

Implement graceful degradation for context overflow situations. Your system should never crash or produce empty responses when hitting context limits. Instead, automatically trigger aggressive summarization, prune non-critical content, or reset to a clean state with a summary of prior work. Ensure users receive explanations when context limits force workflow interruption. This robustness distinguishes production systems from prototypes.

Combine multiple techniques rather than relying on a single approach. Use pruning for routine cleanup, summarization for compressing important information, offloading for large data, atomic tools for efficiency, sub-agents for isolation, and conservative management for reliability. The most effective systems employ all six techniques in appropriate combinations for different scenarios.

Monitor and iterate on your context engineering strategies. What works for early prototypes may not scale to production workloads. Continuously analyze context usage patterns and identify optimization opportunities. A/B test different pruning thresholds and summarization frequencies. Evolve your approach based on real-world usage data rather than theoretical assumptions.

Document your context engineering decisions explicitly. Future maintainers need to understand why pruning occurs at specific thresholds, how summarization prompts were designed, and what information gets offloaded versus kept in context. This documentation prevents well-intentioned changes from breaking carefully tuned context management.

## Conclusion

Context engineering has evolved from an esoteric concern to a fundamental discipline in AI systems engineering. As models grow more capable and workflows become more complex, effective context management increasingly determines system success.

The techniques we’ve explored — pruning, summarization, offloading, atomic tools, context isolation, and conservative management — provide a robust toolkit for production systems.

These aren’t optional optimizations but essential practices for reliable, efficient, and cost-effective AI agents. Teams that master context engineering will build systems that scale gracefully, perform reliably, and deliver value economically.

The field continues to evolve rapidly. New research constantly improves our understanding of how context length affects model behavior. Framework developers integrate increasingly sophisticated context management features into popular tools. Best practices emerge from production experience at companies operating AI systems at scale.

Yet the core principles remain stable: models perform best with focused, relevant context. More isn’t better — better is better. Strategic removal, compression, and isolation of information consistently outperforms naive accumulation of everything.

As you build your next AI agent or LLM application, treat context engineering as a first-class concern. Design your architecture with context management in mind. Implement pruning, summarization, and offloading from the start. Monitor context usage continuously and optimize based on real data. Your users will experience faster, more accurate, more reliable AI interactions as a result.

The invisible discipline of context engineering makes the difference between AI systems that merely work in demos and those that thrive in production. Master these techniques, and you’ll build agents that don’t drown in their own memory but instead leverage it to deliver exceptional results.

# Effective context engineering for AI agents
PublishedSep 29, 2025
Context is a critical but finite resource for AI agents. In this post, we explore strategies for effectively curating and managing the context that powers them.
After a few years of prompt engineering being the focus of attention in applied AI, a new term has come to prominence:**context engineering**. Building with language models is becoming less about finding the right words and phrases for your prompts, and more about answering the broader question of “what configuration of context is most likely to generate our model’s desired behavior?&quot;
**Context**refers to the set of tokens included when sampling from a large-language model (LLM). The**engineering**problem at hand is optimizing the utility of those tokens against the inherent constraints of LLMs in order to consistently achieve a desired outcome. Effectively wrangling LLMs often requires*thinking in context*— in other words: considering the holistic state available to the LLM at any given time and what potential behaviors that state might yield.
In this post, we’ll explore the emerging art of context engineering and offer a refined mental model for building steerable, effective agents.
## Context engineering vs. prompt engineering
At Anthropic, we view context engineering as the natural progression of prompt engineering. Prompt engineering refers to methods for writing and organizing LLM instructions for optimal outcomes (see[our docs](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/build-with-claude/prompt-engineering/overview)for an overview and useful prompt engineering strategies).**Context engineering**refers to the set of strategies for curating and maintaining the optimal set of tokens (information) during LLM inference, including all the other information that may land there outside of the prompts.
In the early days of engineering with LLMs, prompting was the biggest component of AI engineering work, as the majority of use cases outside of everyday chat interactions required prompts optimized for one-shot classification or text generation tasks. As the term implies, the primary focus of prompt engineering is how to write effective prompts, particularly system prompts. However, as we move towards engineering more capable agents that operate over multiple turns of inference and longer time horizons, we need strategies for managing the entire context state (system instructions, tools,[Model Context Protocol](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/docs/getting-started/intro)(MCP), external data, message history, etc).
An agent running in a loop generates more and more data that*could*be relevant for the next turn of inference, and this information must be cyclically refined. Context engineering is the[art and science](https://x.com/karpathy/status/1937902205765607626?lang=en)of curating what will go into the limited context window from that constantly evolving universe of possible information.
![Prompt engineering vs. context engineering](https://www.anthropic.com/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww-cdn.anthropic.com%2Fimages%2F4zrzovbb%2Fwebsite%2Ffaa261102e46c7f090a2402a49000ffae18c5dd6-2292x1290.png&amp;w=3840&amp;q=75)*In contrast to the discrete task of writing a prompt, context engineering is iterative and the curation phase happens each time we decide what to pass to the model.*
## Why context engineering is important to building capable agents
Despite their speed and ability to manage larger and larger volumes of data, we’ve observed that LLMs, like humans, lose focus or experience confusion at a certain point. Studies on needle-in-a-haystack**style benchmarking have uncovered the concept of[context rot](https://research.trychroma.com/context-rot): as the number of tokens in the context window increases, the model’s ability to accurately recall information from that context decreases.
While some models exhibit more gentle degradation than others, this characteristic emerges across all models. Context, therefore, must be treated as a finite resource with diminishing marginal returns. Like humans, who have[limited working memory capacity](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0963721409359277), LLMs have an “attention budget” that they draw on when parsing large volumes of context. Every new token introduced depletes this budget by some amount, increasing the need to carefully curate the tokens available to the LLM.
This attention scarcity stems from architectural constraints of LLMs. LLMs are based on the[transformer architecture](https://arxiv.org/abs/1706.03762), which enables every token to[attend to every other token](https://huggingface.co/blog/Esmail-AGumaan/attention-is-all-you-need)across the entire context. This results in n² pairwise relationships for n tokens.
As its context length increases, a model&#x27;s ability to capture these pairwise relationships gets stretched thin, creating a natural tension between context size and attention focus. Additionally, models develop their attention patterns from training data distributions where shorter sequences are typically more common than longer ones. This means models have less experience with, and fewer specialized parameters for, context-wide dependencies.
Techniques like[position encoding interpolation](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2306.15595)allow models to handle longer sequences by adapting them to the originally trained smaller context, though with some degradation in t

    Title:Why Do Multi-Agent LLM Systems Fail?
    Authors:Mert Cemri, Melissa Z. Pan, Shuyi Yang, Lakshya A. Agrawal, Bhavya Chopra, Rishabh Tiwari, Kurt Keutzer, Aditya Parameswaran, Dan Klein, Kannan Ramchandran, Matei Zaharia, Joseph E. Gonzalez, Ion Stoica            View a PDF of the paper titled Why Do Multi-Agent LLM Systems Fail?, by Mert Cemri and 12 other authors
    View PDF
    HTML (experimental)



    
            Abstract:Despite enthusiasm for Multi-Agent LLM Systems (MAS), their performance gains on popular benchmarks are often minimal. This gap highlights a critical need for a principled understanding of why MAS fail. Addressing this question requires systematic identification and analysis of failure patterns. We introduce MAST-Data, a comprehensive dataset of 1600+ annotated traces collected across 7 popular MAS frameworks. MAST-Data is the first multi-agent system dataset to outline the failure dynamics in MAS for guiding the development of better future systems. To enable systematic classification of failures for MAST-Data, we build the first Multi-Agent System Failure Taxonomy (MAST). We develop MAST through rigorous analysis of 150 traces, guided closely by expert human annotators and validated by high inter-annotator agreement (kappa = 0.88). This process identifies 14 unique modes, clustered into 3 categories: (i) system design issues, (ii) inter-agent misalignment, and (iii) task verification. To enable scalable annotation, we develop an LLM-as-a-Judge pipeline with high agreement with human annotations. We leverage MAST and MAST-Data to analyze failure patterns across models (GPT4, Claude 3, Qwen2.5, CodeLlama) and tasks (coding, math, general agent), demonstrating improvement headrooms from better MAS design. Our analysis provides insights revealing that identified failures require more sophisticated solutions, highlighting a clear roadmap for future research. We publicly release our comprehensive dataset (MAST-Data), the MAST, and our LLM annotator to facilitate widespread research and development in MAS.

└─ Pattern not explicitly stated\n━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━\n```\n\n### Root Cause 4: Prompt Distraction\n\n```\nConversation History Your observation that **AI agents ignore rules and skip instructions** is fundamentally correct and well-documented in research. The key findings:

### 2. Why Agents Skip Rules (Research-Backed)

| Root Cause | Explanation |
|------------|-------------|
| **Attention Scarcity** | Models have finite "attention budget" - can't process all tokens equally |
| **Lost in Middle** | Information in the middle of long contexts is forgotten 60-80% more often |
| **Context Rot** | Quality degrades even within token limits as context grows |
| **Token Competition** | Every rule displaces another - agents must choose what to focus on |
| **Judgment Gaps** | Rules requiring interpretation often get wrong interpretations |
